home.welcome: Welcome to the Tekken 7 Character Selection Quiz!
home.message:
This quiz will try to choose the character you will enjoy playing based on your playstyle and other preferences.
There are no right or wrong answers to the questions - it is only to gauge your preference.
This quiz is meant to serve as a guide to narrow down options for you when you are feeling overwhelmed.
If you already have different character in mind, go for it. The only way to know for sure is to play.
Please feel free to leave feedback on the links provided below.
Have fun!
home.thanks:
Special thanks to Wecka, Lubamartin, Bigcookie, Jayelly, LoseAgainMan, Merv202, DRX_Chanel, GuraTV
...and you!

questions.q1: Do you prefer a male or female character?
questions.q2: Do you want DLC characters, including crossovers, recommended to you?
questions.q3: During a round, what would do you think you'd enjoy most (primary goal)?
questions.q4: What would be something you enjoy second? (Choose the same thing to double down)
questions.q5: How do you see yourself attacking the opponent?
questions.q6: What is another way you can see yourself attacking the opponent? (Choose the same thing to double down)
questions.q7: The opponent is on the ground - what do you want to do? (Okizeme)
questions.q8: Would you want to play a character focused around setups?
questions.q9: Would you want to play a character that focuses on their stances (attack styles)?
questions.q10: Do you value your characters' built in movement? (backdash/sidestep)
questions.q11: How important do you think evasion in a character's moveset should be? (Includes stances and powercrush)
questions.q12: Are you ok with playing characters with Ki gauge and projectiles? (Geese/Akuma/Eliza)
questions.q13:
Do you care about character tiers?: 
(Tiers are subjective, all characters are playable.)
questions.q14:
One last thing, do you have preference on character difficulty?
(Difficulty is subjective, all characters are hard at first.)

answers.neutralgoal: I have no preference/I don't know.
answers.male-only: I strongly prefer a male character.
answers.male-prioritize: I prefer a male character, but it's not essential.
answers.female-only: I strongly prefer a female character.
answers.female-prioritize: I prefer a female character, but it's not essential.
answers.neutral-gender: I don't lean either way. Recommend me a character without considering this.
answers.neutral-dlc: Absolutely, I am willing to buy DLC if the character fits my playstyle.
answers.base-prioritize: I'm ok with it, but please prioritize non-DLC characters.
answers.base-only: Please prioritize characters in the base game. I don't want to buy DLC.
answers.dlc-only: I actually want to try a character in the DLC, prioritize DLC characters.
answers.movement-prioritize: Dashing in and out of range of my opponent's moves.
answers.versatilegoal-prioritize: I prioritize an all-rounder character that has balanced everything.
answers.movement-prefer: Dashing in and out of range of my opponent's moves.
answers.aggression-prefer: Getting aggressively close to my opponent.
answers.versatilegoal-prefer: I prefer an all-rounder character that has balanced everything.
answers.whiff-punish-prioritize: Attacking when the opponent makes a mistake and misses a move.
answers.counterhit-prioritize: Landing a counterhit when my opponent tries to attack.
answers.mixup-prioritize: Aggressive mixups(50/50) that will keep them guessing.
answers.grab-prioritize: Grappling and throwing - they can't break them all.
answers.plus-frame-prioritize: Pressuring with plus frame moves (big/slower moves that stagger the opponent).
answers.poke-prioritize: Poking down the opponent down with a series of low risk moves.
answers.versatileoffense-prioritize: I would prioritize a character that has balanced attack options for all.
answers.whiff-punish-prefer: Attacking when the opponent makes a mistake and misses a move.
answers.counterhit-prefer: Landing a counterhit when my opponent tries to attack.
answers.mixup-prefer: Aggressive mixups(50/50) that will keep them guessing.
answers.grab-prefer: Grappling and throwing - they can't break them all.
answers.plus-frame-prefer: Pressuring with plus frame moves (big/slower moves that stagger the opponent).
answers.poke-prefer: Poking down the opponent down with a series of low risk moves.
answers.versatileoffense-prefer: I would prefer a character that has balanced attack options for all.
answers.aggressiveoki-prefer: I aggressively dash in, looking for a followup mixup.
answers.defensiveoki-prefer: I take it safe and reset to a neutral position.
answers.versatileoki-prefer: I would like a character that benefits from both options equally.
answers.neutral-oki: I don't have an opinion. Please don't take okizeme situations into consideration.
answers.setups-important-prioritize: Absolutely! Please try to recommend me a character that focuses on setups.
answers.setups-important-prefer: I prefer setups, but it doesn't take priority over other options.
answers.setups-unimportant-prioritize: Please try to recommend me characters that don't have setups as their focus.
answers.setups-unimportant-prefer: I prefer no setups, but I am willing to play a setup oriented character.
answers.neutral-setups: I don't really have an opinion/I'm not familiar with setups
answers.stance-heavy-prioritize: Please try to recommend me a character that focuses on stances.
answers.stance-heavy-prefer: I prefer having stances, but it doesn't take priority over other options.
answers.stance-light-prioritize: Please try to recommend me characters that don't have a big focus on stances.
answers.stance-light-prefer: I prefer characters don't focus on stances, but I am willing to play a character that do.
answers.neutral-stance: I don't really have an opinion. Please don't take stances into consideration.
answers.movetier-high-prioritize: It is important that my character has top class movement
answers.movetier-midhigh-prioritize: It is important that my character has at least above average movement.
answers.neutral-movetier: If a character shines in other ways, it is ok if their movement is average/below average.
answers.evasion-high-prioritize: It's very important that my character has high evasion
answers.evasion-midhigh-prioritize: It is important that my character has at least above average evasion.
answers.neutral-evasion: If a character shines in other ways, it is ok if their evasion is average/below average
answers.2d-prioritize: I would enjoy playing characters with a Ki gauge/projectiles.
answers.3d-only: Only recommend characters with NO Ki gauge/projectiles.
answers.neutral-crossover: Please don't take Ki into consideration/I have no preference
answers.neutral-tier: I don't have a strong opinion on tiers, please don't take it into consideration.
answers.gameplan-level-low-prioritize: Recommend easier characters that I can start learning Tekken with.
answers.gameplan-level-high-prioritize: Recommend harder characters that have challenging execution and gameplan.
answers.gameplan-level-mid-prioritize: Recommend characters that isn't too challenging, but not necessarily easy.
answers.neutral-gameplan-level: I don't have a strong preference on character difficulty.
answers.beginner-friendly-only:
I'm trying out fighting games for the first time. Choose a "beginner friendly"character for me.
I understand this is subjective.

results.instructions:
Click on each character to view more details.
Click on View All for all characters now ordered by your preference

Alisa Bosconovitch.name: Alisa Bosconovitch
Alisa Bosconovitch.flavortext:
Alisa has great movement and poke strings, so it is great for fighting in the mid range and look for a whiff punish.
She excels at using her fast pokes to gain a health advantage and leveraging it as the round progresses. While her pokes are great, you will see more value from a well-timed, quick poke than spamming it all the time.
Her stance, destroyer form, is a highly offensive stance that prevents Alisa from ducking or dashing. However, she can fly around with chainsaw powered attacks that are advantageous on block.
Alisa's main gameplan is on the simple side, but if you want to utilize the chainsaw form heavily, there may be more to memorize.
She does fall behind similar characters in terms of damage and combo potential so she is rarer in a tournament setting.
Ultimately, Alisa is a great, beginner friendly character for all the robo-girl enjoyers!

Akuma / Gouki.name: Akuma / Gouki
Akuma / Gouki.flavortext:
As a guest character from Street Fighter, Akuma looks and plays a bit differently, primarily characterized by his active jumping.
Unlike other characters he does not have a rage drive, but he has a special 'meter' system which he uses for terrible terrible damage.
Akuma's various strings from crouchjab and d+3 are very effective at dismantling the opponent's guard, and he also has a powerful d+4 that knocks down characters.
While his damage potential alone lets him be a top-tier character, his gameplan and combo is hard to execute, as well as being more similar to Street Figher than Tekken.
Ultimately, because of his differences, Akuma is not recommended to a new player unless they are well-versed in Street Figher already.

Anna Williams.name: Anna Williams
Anna Williams.flavortext:
Thanks to her amazing mixup potential, Anna can go 50/50 against anyone. Her powerful crouch mixups threaten enemies even from the midrange.
Anna's high combo damage and buffs on key moves lets her trade blows with most of the cast and come out on top.
She has amazing, spammable combo starter moves as well as great poking mixups that let her pressure the opponent infinitely.
Anna has great counterhit moves in all ranges, and has a lot of setup potential through her Chaos Stance.
Anna does have weaker punish and tracking compared to other characters, which does bring her down a peg in the highest level.
Ultimately, Anna's simple gameplan and commands make her a great character to start learning Tekken with.

Armor King.name: Armor King
Armor King.flavortext:
Damage, utility, and a cool design? Armor King truly has it all. The recent buffs have benefitted Armor King in this damage focused meta.
Armor King has high combo damage and wall-carry potential, which are heightened in maps where you can break floors/walls. He has great punishes, panic moves, and moves that combo on counter hits.
Armor King's variety of grabs make sure the enemy crouches often, which he can take advantage of with his many safe mid options.
It is to be noted, however, that all of this only come into play if you have great movement - Armor King's aggression potential relies on wavedashing, and he lacks low attacks that knocks down the opponent.
Ultimately, Armor King is definitely a great character with strong combos and grabs as well as being cool incarnate, but his difficult gameplan makes him more of an advanced character.

Asuka Kazama.name: Asuka Kazama
Asuka Kazama.flavortext:
Asuka is a character modeled after 'offense is the best defense'. Her attacks may put you in a disadvantageous situation, but her parries and panic moves are amazing and quickly let you take back the tempo again.
Her never-ending stream of attacks contain many combo starters, and Asuka has a great, well known combo setup with her unblockable move.
Additionally, Asuka has amazing damage potential in her rage drive and special mount, which gives her some tools for comebacks.
Unfortunately, her poking moves aren't amazing and movement is relatively slow, meaning she has a limit to playing a reactive style.
Her defensive attacks and easy commands mean Asuka is often recommended to new players.

Bob (Robert Richards).name: Bob (Robert Richards)
Bob (Robert Richards).flavortext:
Bob has everything - long reach, high damage, and great movement. His basic attacks are long and strong, which makes it easy for him to keep the enemy at bay.
Bob has many strings that let him get a mental advantage over enemies over whether to complete them. He also has amazing comeback potential through a strong mixup of hellsweep and mid.
Such positive traits are amplified at the wall, especially thanks to Bob's high wall combo damage. In best(worst?) case scenarios, Bob can carry the opponent to the wall and end the game there in the blink of an eye.
Bob is definitely a strong, fun, exciting character to play, but his pickrate does not reflect that, presumably due to his bulkier body.
Ultimately, Bob has a simpler gameplan but with some execution barriers, so he is recommended to players who are more used to the Tekken system.

Bryan Fury.name: Bryan Fury
Bryan Fury.flavortext:
With his high damage moves and combos combined with an unblockable taunt, Bryan definitely made every Tekken fan salivate a little at the thought of playing him with precision. Bryan also happens to be the symbolic character of Knee, the best Tekken player in the world
Bryan's moves generally pack a punch, and his decent wall carry makes him lethal. Bryan's taunt disable's the opponent's guard and lets him chain together a basically unblockable attack.
This makes Bryan especially strong in situations where he has a frame advantage - such as oki situations or after a successful punish, where he can mix up the opponent with his high damage moves.
However, these situations are hard to create because Bryan's movement can be hard to execute, and there are no gimmicky, abusable moves, and his main attacks are relatively slow.
While Bryan doesn't have particularly difficult execution and a easy to understand gameplan, the gameplan is hard to actually get right, making him frustrating if you are just starting to play the game.

Claudio Serafino.name: Claudio Serafino
Claudio Serafino.flavortext:
Claudio has a quite interesting gameplan via his Ira (WR+2), a very strong high move that gives you a maassive advantage even when blocked.
Because of the high guardback level, the opponent will find themselves with their back to the wall after blocking just a few Iras. While most of the cast mixup the mids and lows, Claudio mixes up the highs and mids.
Claudio has a variety of great mids to compliment this, most of which are even stronger at the wall. His hopkick has ome of the best hitboxes in the game, which lets him take advantage of his opponents' haphazard attempts to take back control.
Claudio's Starburst form unlocks more damaging moves, letting him put on even more pressure. However, he does have weaker lows, and can find difficult to play out the game if his hopkicks and punishable mids are blocked.
Ultimately, Claudio is a great character for new players thanks to his easy combos and simple gameplan.

Devil Jin.name: Devil Jin
Devil Jin.flavortext:
Devil Jin is the most well-balanced Mishima of the trio (Heihachi, Kazuya, Devil Jin).
Thanks to his amazing highs, strong counter hit and mixup options, Devil Jin can play well from ahead or behind. Unfortunately due to recent patches, his mixup efficiency is a lot weaker with more risk and less reward. Combined with his difficult execution requirement, these are some reasons we see less Devil Jin in tournaments today.
Even so, Devil Jin has a great pressure from wavedash and plenty of tools to dish out damage.
Ultimately, because of the execution barrier and lower returns, Devil Jin is not recommended for players new to Tekken.

Eddy Gordo.name: Eddy Gordo
Eddy Gordo.flavortext:
Eddy is a character that can really take advantage of the opponent's (lack of) matchup knowledge. He has traditionally shined in the hands of the most inexperienced players mashing against equally inexperienced opponents.
His moves with long reach and confusing stances, with mixups involving string after string wears down your opponent both mentallly and physically.
Eddy has great moves that transition him into his stances in an advantageous position, rewarding him for pressing aggressively.
His strong mixups and great keepaway moves make them easy options to use. However, Eddy does struggle with a lack of good sidestep, and many of his setups will not work against an experienced opponent, which make it a struggle to actually learn Tekken with Eddy.
Therefore, Eddy is recommended to more experienced players looking for a challenge, or completely new players that just want a slight dip into what Tekken is like

Eliza.name: Eliza
Eliza.flavortext:
Although she is a Tekken original character, Eliza actually has a ki-gauge. Eliza focuses on using her divekick pressure to lock in opponents.
Because of how scary it is, opponents who are not familiar with Eliza often end up losing after blocking for the entire round. Eliza also has some great combos on counter hits and find success in poking down opponents through string and divekick pressure.
Compared to Geese and Akuma, Eliza has a quicker meter fill rate, which lets her freely use the powerful meter based moves in her arsenal. She is still a very difficult character that requires a lot of mechanical prowess and gameplay knowledge to play well, however, as most of her moves don't have a lot of damage.
For the mentioned reasons, Eliza is ultimately recommended to experienced players that are looking for a vampire character with flashy combos, and is not recommended for beginners.

Fahkumram.name: Fahkumram
Fahkumram.flavortext:
With his long legs and muscular physique, Fahkumram's fight style is very fitting with his looks, as he abuses his long reach for explosive damage.
Fahkumram aggravates his opponents through his long pokes, and suddenly comes in with a meaty 3+4 counterhit - unfortunately, a lot of his other tools have been nerfed over time so he is not a top tier pick anymore.
Fahkumram thrives off counterhits, but it is difficult to connect with counterhit moves with great reward, so he has become more reliant on whiff punishing, poking, and mixing up opponents with his strings.
Overall, Fahkumram still sees some potential thanks to his satisfying hit effect and long reach, and can really benefit from an aggressive gameplan.
While his gameplay and reach may be fitting for a newer player, it is to be noted that his combos may be a little hard if you are completely new to the game.

Feng Wei.name: Feng Wei
Feng Wei.flavortext:
Feng is an amazing, well-rounded character that excels in everything. As a testament to this, there are many ways you can play Feng.
Some players play him defensively, poking down opponents, and fish for a big hit. Others put more weight on his back-turn or kenpo stances, forcing their opponents into a deadly mixup.
Feng has moves that come with auto parrying which naturally integrate defense into his offense, and has amazing returns on his counterhit moves. Not only that, his combos have great damage and decent wall carry.
Feng has received quite a few nerfs but he is still a great character that has a simple, easy to execute gameplan. Ultimately, this makes him a great character for beginners to start learning Tekken with.

Gigas.name: Gigas
Gigas.flavortext:
Gigas is a big red hulk and he plays like one too, covering his slow movement with heavy hitting punches and long reach.
His combo damage is great especially when you consider how simple it can be, and has a decent low option that quickly racks up damage.
Gigas' goliath stance lets him get in a threatening mixup as well as push the opponent to the wall, but he does struggle in the movement and counterhit department, making him vulnerable in close combat situations.
Overall, Gigas is a honest, easy to learn defensive character that beginners can pick up and learn Tekken easily with.

Geese Howard.name: Geesse Howard
Geese Howard.flavortext:
Geese Howard is another 2D game guest character like Akuma - but he does seem to have integrated into the Tekken system a better than the latter. Still, he relies heavily on meter management and has quite a few jump based options that may feel alien to the traditional Tekken player.
Despite multiple nerfs, Geese still has flashy, high damage combos, rewarding parries, and a nice toolkit all around. He doesn't have a sweeping low, but that doesn't stop Geese from doing things that you may need to clutch out the victory.
Despite this, because his mechanics are decently foreign, he isn't recommended to new players trying to learn Tekken, but if you are used to 2D fighters, his execution demand is actually not as scary as it seems.

Ganryu.name: Ganryu
Ganryu.flavortext:
Ganryu is a great character that is held back by his personality and looks.
Despite those major flaws, in-game Ganryu sees a lot of value via aggression, poking and mixing up opponents in the close range through various attack routes. Even when Ganryu is getting pressured, he has great panic moves to mash and put him back in control.
Ganryu has decent combo damage with wallcarry, and truly shines in the face of his opponents. However, he does struggle getting there as he has poor tools to use in the midrange, so can be playing from the back foot until he lands a combo.
His aggressive gameplan is pretty simple in thory, but his short reach can make it difficult to create the situations Ganryu wants.
Ultimately, because he can be frustrating to play until one gets used to his range, Ganryu the easiest for people just starting to play Tekken.

Heihachi Mishima.name: Heihachi Mishima
Heihachi Mishima.flavortext:
As the oldest surviving Mishima, Heihachi continues to have an image of the strong, experienced final boss fighter in the Tekken series.
Unlike the other two Mishimas, Heihachi has a weaker hellsweep that does not knock down on hit, which is compensated by a versatile array of strong mids. While he does not have a hellsweep, Heihachi still has a variety of high risk lows thich let him keep the traditional low/mid mixup.
But, his mids are so good that Heihachi has a lot of setup potential and lower wavedash reliance.
Heihachi has a lot of abusable moves, so a player starting with him may be able to achieve some level of success, but his gameplan is still risky and difficult to execute, so beware you may get stuck in a rut.
Because of those reasons, Heihachi is recommended for more experienced players.

Hwoarang.name: Hwoarang
Hwoarang.flavortext:
Hwoarang is the only Korean character in Tekken 7, but he has popularity thanks to his cool moveset and looks.
Hwoarang is very good at flowcharting - chaining moves together in an almost mindless way, the possible combinations are endless. His strong low poke and a plethora of plus frame moves can let him take perfect rounds as he forces the opponent to keep guessing when their turn is.
His flashy, diverse, strong combos really add to the fun of playing Hwoarang. Hwoarang's launchers have a very good risk/reward ratio and are almost spammable. Additionally, he has great close and mid range tools that can really shake up the opponent.
Unfortunately, Hwoarang does not benefit from a defensive playstyle as he has weaker punish, and his stances leave him unable to block. As such, Hwoarang may have trouble taking back the tempo after losing it.
Ultimately, Hwoarang is recommended for advanced players as he requires a lot of memorization in addition to a challenging execution barrier.

Jack - 7.name: Jack-7
Jack - 7.flavortext:
Jack is a big robot that comes with great poke and keepaway as well as a strong low-risk high-reward mixup.
Most of Jack's moves are long and his decent backdash capabilities let him easily control the distance between his opponent. He also has great low pokes and quick counterhits, which lets him hold his own in close combat. His great strings and pressure building at the wall is amazing, and the game becomes a lot easier as Jack when you land a combo on the opponent and carry them to the wall.
However, Jack does have a larger hitbox which subject him to more damaging combos, and his sidestep is below average, making it hard for him to get out of being pressured, especially at the wall.
Jack also does have a weaker combo game, but the simple, effective combos as well as easy to learn gameplan makes Jack a very good starting character for new Tekken players.

Jin Kazama.name: Jin Kazama
Jin Kazama.flavortext:
Jin is kind of a Mishima, but the most glaring difference is that he relies on his safe mid options more than aggressive wavedashing.
Jin can push away enemies and hold them at midrange with his many keepaway pokes, and he can fish for some big damage through his EWHF counter hit.
Jin can play out the game safely and defensively, and take time to whittle down the opponent. Jin has a parry lets him handle opponent's string based attacks with confidence.
However, Jin can struggle in a close range battle against opponents that break through his defensive barrier.
Jin definitely has a lot of tools, but his difficult gameplan can make him challenging for newer players to play.

Josie Rizal.name: Josie Rizal
Josie Rizal.flavortext:
Don't fool for her crying at the start - once the game starts, Josie Rizal does a U turn into a deadly mixup machine that pokes down the opponent with her switch stance and crouch dash.
Josie forces the opponent to freeze through her string mindgame, then threatens to end them through a switch stance counterhit or a crouchdash mixup. Her combo damage is on the lower side, but it is easy to learn and there is quite a bit of variety.
Also, Josie's great, low risk high reward combo starters and amazing punish tools more than make up for it.
Josie does struggle a little in that she does not have a hard hitting low that knocks down opponents, and can be open to fast counterhits and high crushes.
Josie does have a little bit of an execution barrier, but her gameplan and combos themselves are easy to execute, so she is a great character to start learning Tekken with.

Julia Chang.name: Julia Chang
Julia Chang.flavortext:
Julia is a native american activist streamer(???) that boasts some of the best mixups in Tekken.
Her moves don't have massive damage, but they usually come in strings with massive return potential. When the opponent stays on guard, that leaves Julia open to run up and grab them or start her crouch mixups. Julia has very good counterhit rewards, and her combos have insane wallcarry that lets her take the opponent to the wall from anywhere on the map. At the wall, Julia can take the win by trapping them in her hard hitting mixups.
Julia's main strings are very good for mindgames, and she has tools for closing the gap from any distance, making her a great aggressive character.
While her gameplan is relatively simple, Julia's moves have some execution barrier, so she is recommended for players who are a little more used to playing Tekken.

Katarina Alvez.name: Katarina Alvez
Katarina Alvez.flavortext:
Katarina has insane damage potential only rivaled by a few other characters.
Her combos are very strong and have great wall carry, and even the less complicated ones have respectable damage. Katarina amplifies this by having many great counterhit launchers, and even her regular launchers have decent stats on them.
However, her lows do have quite a bit of risk, so it is smart to be wary of spamming too much of it and getting a costly punish.
Overall, Katarina has a simple, easy to follow gameplan, easy execution, and high damage combos accessible from most of her good moves, so she is definitely a great character to start learning Tekken with.

Kazumi Hachijo Mishima.name: Kazumi Hachijo Mishima
Kazumi Hachijo Mishima.flavortext:
Kazumi can feel very clean and reserved to play.
Her amazing base movement lets her land meaningful whiff punishes after avoiding the opponent's attacks. Furthermore, Kazumi's basic attacks are very strong, giving her an advantage over other characters in the neutral. Additionally, Kazumi can also get aggressive at times, using her while running moves and fearless warrior stance.
Kazumi sees a lot of value in poking down enemies and stopping their movement with her amazing homing mid, and getting in a nice magic 4 counter for some damage. However, because Kazumi's normal hit launchers are short and risky, the players' defensive abilities are pushed to the limit, and therefore may feel pressure other characters don't have to deal with.
While her execution is on the easy side, her gameplan can get very difficult, so she is recommended for players who are more used to the Tekken system.

Kazuya Mishima.name: Kazuya Mishima
Kazuya Mishima.flavortext:
Kazuya Mishima is one of the most iconic characters in Tekken.
As the gold standard Mishima, his powerful mixups that stem through wavedashing incentivize aggressive play, but he can also be played defensively thanks to his amazing punish potential.
Kazuya can trade his rage to turn into devil mode, in which the EWGF turns into a mid, creating much stronger mixup potential to stage a comeback.
Kazuya is a very popular character that many people choose to play when they start Tekken. However, because he requires a certain level of mechanical skill to properly show his potential, he is not a character recommended for beginners.

King.name: King
King.flavortext:
Aside from his jaguar mask, King is known for his strong grapple options, but his base moves aren't bad at all.
Many King players look for a mid range whiff punish, or a sudden switch to a close range fight spearheaded by a pushing counter or a throw. King's close range options aren't bad as he does have some quick counterhit options.
As King's chain throws can really chunk down health, King always has comeback potential no matter how low his health may be. Because many of his throws start with the same motion, everyone is subjected to King's grapple mindgame.
However, if the opponent breaks throws consistantly, King really struggles to play out the rest of the game, especially because most of his mids put him in a disadvantage when guarded.
While King's chain throws are very strong, especially to newcomers, a lot of them can be difficult to memorize and execute.
Overall, King is a solid character choice recommended for players more experienced to the Tekken system

Kuma / Panda.name: Kuma / Panda
Kuma / Panda.flavortext:
The Tekken bears have a long reach that help with its mid range pokes and whiff punishes.
Their short legs and standing posture make their neutral hitboxes a little different from other characters, and you can see opponents misjudge the distance to use their lows and whiff. The bears' long range whiff punishes are perfect to capitalize on such blunders, and the quick 1,1,1 string is also a scary, counter hit combo starter.
The bears' hunting stance gets them on all four legs and gives them access to stronger mixups and pressure the opponent.
Unfortunately, because they are such big characters, bears are commonly subjected to their own special combos that deal extra damage against them, and their weak sidestep makes it hard for them to navigate out of the walls.
Bears don't have particularly difficult execution and their long reach lets them take advantageous fights. They are also equipped with moves that can be very difficult for other new players to deal with, so if you are looking to check out Tekken with some cute animals, the bears might be for you.

Kunimitsu.name: Kunimitsu
Kunimitsu.flavortext:
The kunoichi Kunimitsu is a character defined by mixup after mixup through her strings, stances, and okizeme situations.
Each mixup doesn't have the greatest damage, but as the mixups continue to stack up, the damage does as well. Not only that, Kunimitsu has amazing movement and great whiff punish and poke tools to take advantage of it. She also has a variety of grapple options, making her a very versatile character with options for every situation.
Kunimitsu can leverage her strengths to play out the game on her own terms in an almost flowcharting way.
However, to fully utilize her potential, the player must never stop moving, and a moment's lapse in concentration can result in the opponent taking control of the game.
As such, Kunimitsu does have some challenging elements to her gameplay and is recommended for more experienced players

Lars Alexandersson.name: Lars Alexandersson
Lars Alexandersson.flavortext:
Lars enjoyed great popularity in the previous Tekken games, but he has been struggling in Tekken 7 despite constant buffs since his introduction.
Lars actually has a tool for every occaision, making him a versatile character, but he shines the most in outstanding combos with high damage and wall carry potential. On the offense, Lars is a very good whiff punisher thanks to his great base movement.
Lars' main problems come from his lackluster rage drive and risky lows that see low returns. As a result, he is almost forced into looking for whiff punishes, which the opponennt takes advantage of.
Ultimately, using Lars requires one to use his diverse moves in correct situations, and because of his risky lows, Lars is recommended for players who are familiar with Tekken.

Leroy Smith.name: Leroy Smith
Leroy Smith.flavortext:
As a rare Wing Chun based fighting game character, Leroy received a lot of positive attention even before his release, and he is definitely one of the most well made DLC characters in Tekken.
He was also the hot potato of Tekken balance for a while, being so OP to the point where 6 out of 8 characters at EVO were Leroy. Leroy has moves with built in parries and has a strong string based mindgame, and also has strong lows for amazing comeback potential.
Leroy has decent range in his keepaway lows, but does have short reach otherwise, meaning he must play more reactively if the opponent manages to get some distance from him. Combined with his recent nerfs, he did drop a notch from when he first released.
Even after all this though, Leroy is a very strong character with a easy gameplan that can be realized with a little bit of practice. As such, Leroy is a great character especially for newcomers to learn Tekken with.

Lee Chaolan.name: Lee Chaolan
Lee Chaolan.flavortext:
Like staying defensive? Enjoy comboing the opponent from wall to wall? Enjoy the elegance of keepaway?
Excellent - you should be considering Lee Chaolan. Lee is a classic defensive character who slams the attacking player back to their corner of the stage.
This stands out even more in the lower ranks where players have little experience playing against defensive players.
It also does mean you have a risk of becoming too reliant on playing keepaway and may have trouble learning other basics.
Lee excels in throwing out counterhits while poking down the opponent, and his combos have one of the best wall carries in the game.
His sliding mixups allow him to control the pace of the game as he wants.
While not stance heavy, Lee's hitman stance does give him benefits, especially his powercrush that can preserve his attack momentum.
While his looks and moves give him a big fanbase, he is still mid tier character, and his more demanding execution makes him a character for experienced players.

Lei Wulong.name: Lei Wulong
Lei Wulong.flavortext:
Lei Wulong's identity comes from his many stances - and nobody knows what will come from it, not even the player himself.
His unique backdash using the backturn stance lets him run away quickly, evading combat entirely after attacking. This may lead to Lei players struggling to adjust to other characters' traditional backdashing.
Lei has a unique gameplay option based on this such as poking and running away or forcing a mixup then running away. This non traditional style of gameplay is both a pro and con for Lei.
His setups and risky mixups make it easy for him to get wins in lower ranks, but lose its power quickly against someone who knows Lei.
Lei has a dedicated following thanks to his stylish combos and enjoyable gameplay moments.
If you start with Lei, you will eventually have to struggle to re-learn Tekken due to it being hard to learn fundamentals. But hey, it will be fun!

Leo Kliesen.name: Leo Kliesen
Leo Kliesen.flavortext:
Leo has amazing mixups that shine at the wall, but thanks to their more recent buffs, Leo can truly flex their versatile potential and find damage in any situation.
Leo's buffs let them utilize his long df2 more for effective whiff punishes and mixups, and their stance is very useful for poking down opponents. Leo has tools to approach the enemy easily from the midrange.
Up close, their various counter hits, homing moves, parries, and moves with high evasive traits let Leo quickly get out from high pressure situations.
However, Leo can find it difficult to play if they are stuck in the midrange, and some of their moves have wonky hitboxes that may whiff at close range. Because of this, it may be a struggle trying to keep continuous pressure on the opponent.
Overall, Leo has a lower execution barrier and plenty of aggressive options, they will be a great character to choose regardless of your experience level.

Lidia Sobieska.name: Lidia Sobieska
Lidia Sobieska.flavortext:
Surprisingly the prime minister of Poland, Lidia ruled with an iron fist for most of season 4. Unfortunately, the most recent nerfs to her have taken her down quite a few tiers.
Aside from that though, Lidia has great mindgames based around her poke strings and great movement, making her a versatile character. Lidia's powerful low and stance mixups let her play out the round in various ways, and she has tools to control the distance between her and the opponent.
Lidia's combos are flashy and powerful, but they may take some practice to get down properly.
Her gameplan is pretty simple and she sees a lot of return from an aggressive playstyle, which makes Lidia one of the easier characters to play, but you may be feeling the weight of her nerfs if you have been player her since release.

Lili (Emile de Rochefort).name: Lili (Emile de Rochefort)
Lili (Emile de Rochefort).flavortext:
Lili has the best sidestep in the game, bestowing upon her both offense and defense.
Dancing around the opponent, Lili operates off her pokes and plus frames. Because she can sidestep fast lows, opponents trying to slowly poke Lili down will always find themselves on the losing end.
Lili has both highs and mids that give her a frame advantage, making it hard for opponents to stand nor crouch to counter her.
However, it is important to note that both Lili's offense and defense stems from her movement, making her an easy character to get into but a hard character to master.
Lili is recommended for anyone who is looking for a fighter that can box in the opponent through graceful movement.
